#Text=Horseback ( Comanche )
#Text=Horseback ( Comanche , Tʉhʉya Kwahipʉ
#Text=" horse back " ) was a Nokoni Comanche chief .

column1: #Text=Young man : warrior and war chief

#Text=In his prime , he made his career under the elder Huupi-pahati ( " Tall Tree " ) , head chief of the Nokoni band , and Quenah-evah ( " Eagle Drink " ) , second chief and later successor to Huupi-pahati himself possibly after the smallpox and cholera epidemics occurred in 1849 ; during the 1840s and 1850s he gained a good fame as a war leader against the Comanche 's Indian enemies and a raider through Texas .

column1: #Text=Diplomat and peaceful leader

#Text=In 1861 , along with the Yamparika head chief Ten Bears and the Penateka chiefs Tosahwi ( " White Knife " ) and Asa-havey ( " Milky Way " ) , went to Fort Cobb where they met General Albert Pike ( C.S.A. ) , and the Comanche chiefs ( including Quena-evah ) signed for an allegiance with the Confederate States of America .
#Text=He became head chief of the Nokoni after Quena-evah 's death , possibly in 1866 .

#Text=Not a long time after Peta Nocona 's death about 1864 , and having become Parra-ocoom ( " Bull Bear " ) the new first chief of the Kwahadi Comanche , Kobe ( Wild Horse ) second Chief of Kwahadi took with him the two adolescent sons of the dead Nokoni chief , Quanah Parker and Pecos , to complete their training as young men and warriors .

#Text=Horseback signed for the Nokoni the Medicine Lodge Treaty ( Oct. 21 1867 ) , emerging as the leader of the " peaceful " faction of the band , but the second-ranking chief , Big Red Meat , took the leadership of the uncompromising faction , and on the same " hostile " line was Tahka ( " Arrowpoint " ) , war chief of Horseback 's own party .

#Text=On December 12 , 1868 , while Horseback was not in his village in the spot after known as Soldier Spring , a battle occurred there against 3rd Cavalry and 37th Infantry U.S. troops ; the soldiers came on the village and the war chief Tahka reacted against the " long knives " leading the Nokoni warriors to fight ; the Nokoni were defeated , Tahka being killed in the battle , and the village was burnt and stocks destroyed . [ 1 ]
#Text=Attack on Horseback 's village in the Antelope Hills
#Text=On December 19 , 1868 a large Comanche and Kiowa band faced a company of 10th Cavalry ( maj .
#Text=M.H. Kidd ) on the way from Fort Arbuckle to Fort Cobb .
#Text=On December 25 , six companies of the 6th Cavalry and one company of 37 Infantry ( maj .

#Text=A.W. Evans ) , on the way from Fort Bascom ( New Mexico ) to the Antelope Hills , came on the Nokoni village ( about 60 tipis ) of Horseback and Arrowpoint , where Yamparika chief Howea was as a visitor ; Horseback , the peaceful civil chief , was not in the camp , and Arrowpoint ’s blood was still boiling after the Washita massacre .

#Text=Seeing the soldiers arriving , and being taunted by the Kiowa allies , Arrowpoint , the war chief , led the Comanche warriors in a charge , but he was killed and the village and the stocks went destroyed .
#Text=Kiowa warriors led by Manyi-ten came to take part in the fight ; only one soldiers was killed .
#Text=In December 1868 , exhausted after lack of food and freezing weather , the Nokoni went to Fort Cobb and there surrendered . [ 2 ]
#Text=The last fight for freedom

#Text=Like Tosawi , Horseback managed to keep out the Nokoni preventing their involvement in the Red River War in 1873 – 1874 , but only a faction of Nokoni band followed him along the " peace road " , while Piaru-ekaruhkapu joined the hostile Comanche and Kiowa faction , uniting himself and his Nokoni warriors to Quanah Parker , Parra-ocoom , Kobay-oburra ( " Wild Horse " ) , Kobay-otoho ( " Black Horse " ) , Isatai'i , and their Quahadi Comanche , to Mow-way and his Kotsoteka , to Tabananika ( " Sound-of-the-Sunrise " ) , Isa-rosa ( " White Wolf " ) and Hitetetsi aka Tuwikaa-tiesuat ( " Little Crow " ) , son to Ten Bears , and their Yamparika , and to the Kiowa led by Guipago , Satanta , Zepko-ete ( " Big Bow " ) , Tsen-tainte ( " White Horse " ) and Mamanti ( " He Walking-above " ) .
#Text=The sunset years

#Text=After the Palo Duro campaign ( 1874 ) and the surrendering of the last hostile Comanche groups coming back from the Staked Plains , he was appointed by the Army as head chief of all the Comanches , and was ordered to pick out the " worst " Comanche , to send them to Fort Marion , Florida ; the same happened to Tene-angopte for the Kiowas , and the Kiowa chief pointed out 27 chiefs and warriors , but Horseback was able to sacrifice only nine men ( one Black Horse , but probably not Kobay-otoho third chief of the Quahadi band , and eight " outlawed " warriors ) , preventing the deportation of all the defeated chiefs ( but , unfortunately , not the life of Parra-ocoom , dead on June 27 – 28 , 1874 , during the Adobe Walls fighting , and that of Piaru-ekaruhkapu , dead in the icehouse – temporarily used as a jail – of Fort Sill on January 1 , 1875 .
#Text=Together with Quanah and some of the old chiefs , Horseback was a constant point of reference for the Comanche people in the reservation until his death in 1888 .
